title: How to Block Yarn

steps.headline: Assemble the materials.
steps.description:
For this project, you will need:
Your hand-made yarn based work
A tub or a bowl of lukewarm water
A small mat or a blocking mat (found in hobby stores)
Thumbtacks or pins.

steps.headline: Soak your work of yarn in the water.
steps.description: Make sure the water is room temperature, as cold water and hot water can ruin your hard work and cause your work to stiffen or shrink.

steps.headline: Once your work is thoroughly soaked, place it on the blocking mat and smooth it out.
steps.description: Blocking mats are more expensive than normal mats. You can place your work on a soft mat, such as a yoga mat. It doesn't make any difference.

steps.headline: Once you have smoothed out your work, take the box of pins and adjust the wool in whichever shape or form that you want it be.
steps.description: Apply the pins all over your work, until you are satisfied with how it looks. However, be sure to apply the pins straight, because once you block your work, you can't undo anything. If you are blocking a scarf, using the pins, you can take the edges of the scarf to uncurl them and pin them on so they stretch. You can get as carried away as you want––apply as many pins as you like. However, make sure you like how your work looks before letting it dry. Once you block it, you can't undo anything.

steps.headline: Let your work dry thoroughly.
steps.description: Let it dry in a nice place, away from direct sun and too much heat. Once dried, your work is now water-blocked.

steps.headline: Gather the materials.
steps.description:
For this project, you will need:
Your yarn-based work
Pins or thumbtacks
A spray bottle filled with lukewarm water.

steps.headline: Note that the blocking process is different this time.
steps.description: Pin your yarn work down before blocking. Make sure that you like how it looks before spraying.

steps.headline: Fill the spray bottle with water.
steps.description: Then spray away! This is much easier to do as you won't have to deal with heavy, wet yarn.

steps.headline: Let your yarn dry thoroughly.
steps.description: Once dried, the yarn-based work is blocked.

steps.headline: Gather the materials.
steps.description:
For this project, you will need:
Your yarn-based work
Pins or thumbtacks
An iron.

steps.headline: Pin your work down on the mat.
steps.description: Heat the iron fully (on some irons you have to wait until the little red light turns off). A fully-heated iron is best, because then you can do the blocking faster.

steps.headline: Once your yarn-based work is pinned, use the steam button on the iron and steam the wool.
steps.description: Be careful, you will have to adjust the yarn-based work a bit every time, don't burn your fingers!

steps.headline: Let your work dry.
steps.description: The drying process will only take about an hour, unlike the previous two methods.

text:
Water Blocking Assemble the materials. For this project, you will need:
Your hand-made yarn based work
A tub or a bowl of lukewarm water
A small mat or a blocking mat (found in hobby stores)
Thumbtacks or pins. Soak your work of yarn in the water. Make sure the water is room temperature, as cold water and hot water can ruin your hard work and cause your work to stiffen or shrink. Once your work is thoroughly soaked, place it on the blocking mat and smooth it out. Blocking mats are more expensive than normal mats. You can place your work on a soft mat, such as a yoga mat. It doesn't make any difference. Once you have smoothed out your work, take the box of pins and adjust the wool in whichever shape or form that you want it be. Apply the pins all over your work, until you are satisfied with how it looks. However, be sure to apply the pins straight, because once you block your work, you can't undo anything. If you are blocking a scarf, using the pins, you can take the edges of the scarf to uncurl them and pin them on so they stretch. You can get as carried away as you want––apply as many pins as you like. However, make sure you like how your work looks before letting it dry. Once you block it, you can't undo anything. Let your work dry thoroughly. Let it dry in a nice place, away from direct sun and too much heat. Once dried, your work is now water-blocked. Spray-Blocking Gather the materials. For this project, you will need:
Your yarn-based work
Pins or thumbtacks
A spray bottle filled with lukewarm water. Note that the blocking process is different this time. Pin your yarn work down before blocking. Make sure that you like how it looks before spraying. Fill the spray bottle with water. Then spray away! This is much easier to do as you won't have to deal with heavy, wet yarn. Let your yarn dry thoroughly. Once dried, the yarn-based work is blocked. Steam-Blocking Gather the materials. For this project, you will need:
Your yarn-based work
Pins or thumbtacks
An iron. Pin your work down on the mat. Heat the iron fully (on some irons you have to wait until the little red light turns off). A fully-heated iron is best, because then you can do the blocking faster. Once your yarn-based work is pinned, use the steam button on the iron and steam the wool. Be careful, you will have to adjust the yarn-based work a bit every time, don't burn your fingers! Let your work dry. The drying process will only take about an hour, unlike the previous two methods.
